review_title: Mercer is a great place to work!
pros: Friendly community, good benefits, encourage personal growth!
cons: Have to work for three years before considered for free graduate degree.

pros: u get experience to put on resume and could be fun
cons: u don't get paid. yeah u dont.

review_title: Nice place to work but the insurance is horrible
pros: The people are nice and the culture is great
cons: The insurance and the management of the insurance plan is horrible. Unless you are going for your once a year regularly scheduled check up be prepared to pay $700 dollars out of pocket for any nonemergency care. Even if you go to a standard check up if your Dr orders something that isn't considered part of the standard testing be prepared to pay even if it is in network. The dental plan is not worth it and isn't straight forward. The medical isn't required to meet the ACA requirements so don't expect the usual. Also the plan is privately run so while the staff is nice and answers the phone some times they just don't know the answer, the websites are glitchy and it can 6 months+ from them to process payment. So don't be surprised if you receive a bill from a provider 6 months later.

pros: Remote work, work-life balance, growth Opportunities
cons: Subject matter experts are desired over individuals who can complete tasks.

pros:
* tuition waivers for employees and dependents 
* working with students who really do want to change the world
* able to participate in campus events
* good coworkers
* some departments are able to function as cohesive units (depends on leadership)
cons:
* lack of compassion in administration
* required employees to be on-site during COVID unless they were willing to jump through hoops and disclose personal medical information
* some employees are allowed to work from out of state and not be on campus - it all depends on who will go to bat for you
* the bottom line is what matters
* faculty is afraid to step out of line or stand up to administration

review_title: A Great University with a Overworked Staff
job_title: Associate Director of Student Financial Services in Macon, GA
pros:
~Excellent Institution with a focus on philanthropy.
~Great Students
~Administration is actively working to raise the profile of the University
~Very good reputation in the state and community
~Most folks there are honestly doing their best to do the right thing
cons:
~Administration didn't plan for success. Lots of student growth but no change in number of support staff 
~Middle Management will fudge details and mislead both their employees and the Executive team about what's needed to complete a mandate from administration which leads to poor moral beneath and incorrect impressions that everything's great at the Administration level.
~Very poor facilities. Had a roach fall from the ceiling onto a student (Connell Student Center)
~Middle Management does little to encourage career actual growth relying on kitschy self help books. They say they're invested in you but when someone actually tries to move up, they get sabotaged more often than encouraged.

pros: I have great flexibility when I work the 20 hours per week. I work with great colleagues. The campus is  beautiful and well landscaped. Being primarily a post grad campus, the students are serious about their studies, so they are wonderful to work with. The administration of the entire Mercer University seems to minimize the importance of the non academic departments on the Atlanta campus
cons: The low hourly pay is a definite drawback. The job posting requires much more than the listing of the required high school diploma. The opportunity for promotion is nil, and the advancement in pay has been only pennies an hour over the 6 years that I've been employed.

review_title: I gained valuable teaching experience as I completed my Master's and Doctoral degrees in French Literature.
job_title: Lecturer; Graduate Teaching & Research Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: Cultural diversity of students, faculty, and staff and cutting-edge resources for my Discipline.
cons: Should one's employer discover that he or she has particular skills and talents that one's colleagues do not possess, he or she can easily be exploited for demonstrating with high caliber those very rare qualities.

review_title: Good first job out of college
pros: As an admissions counselor you get to travel and talk about the school. You also learn skills such as sales, budget, etc. Had a good time doing this but it is not something to do forever.  You also get a lot of freedom in the office.
cons:
Lack of upward mobility
Low pay
work weekends
dealing with 16-18 year old prospective students can get annoying
lack of professional development

review_title: Not a bad place to start your career
pros: work was not that difficult, young staff, opportunity to travel, get basic business skills. If you are fresh out of college and looking for a job, admissions is a great place to start. It gives you skills in higher ed and business.
cons: no room for advancement, management was not trained, some staff choose to put their work onto others and faced no consequences, weekend work

review_title: Good, but could use many improvements
pros: Strong strategic plan and attention to the plan and in many departments, faculty seem to get along well, and faculty are dedicated to students for the most part.
cons: Most difficulties relate to the detachment of administration to the real and everyday issues faced by faculty.  Administrative leadership seems to have few resources to develop junior faculty in a meaningful way.  Mercer has a lot of appeal, but there are critical gaps in growing the capabilities of the faculty.

review_title: It was the best of times...it was the worst of times.
pros: Depending on your department and your supervisor, Mercer can be a great place to work.  While I was there, the benefits were great including a very low deductible (less than $1000) for health insurance, free bonus vacation days during Christmas  when the university as closed, staff appreciation days, free tickets to athletic and arts events, and a beautiful campus.  HR is probably one of the best offices I have worked with in my career.  Most faculty and staff are warm and easy to work with.
cons:
As the new football program emerged and basketball program got better and Mercer's non-academic interests such as Newtown Macon and College Hill programs with the Knight Foundation got bigger, the focus on regular students and academics seemed to diminish.  I saw colleagues from other departments fight for funding to keep their programs at the highest level.  I saw one dean retire early because he was done fighting for money his program brought in, that was being used by others.  Make one wrong move, and the president will make sure you are gone.  Too many good people have "retired", "moved on" or "volunteered to leave" while trying to make a positive difference.

I also observed folks moving on because there was no way for them to really move forward in their careers, no true promotional opportunities, and rise hikes were very limited due to strict budgets.

review_title: Mercer University is an ethical employer with integrity.
pros: Very professional atmosphere, diverse population in workforce and student body
cons: Compensation package not the best. I personally did not care for medical insurance plan, did not offer much coverage for anything and premiums were not economically priced. Also, some jobs at Mercer (not all) pay only once a month, this can be difficult for someone just securing employment, or for someone on a tight budget who needs a bi-weekly income.

review_title: Wonderful community, many options for growth
pros: Family atmosphere, chance to get involved with directly with students and in the Macon community, very supportive managers and friendly staff, tons of opportunity to do new things and make a name for yourself
cons:
A little old-fashioned when it comes to updating technology
Pay isn't competitive with national averages
Senior level directors sometimes more concerned with image than integrity

pros: The faculty and staff get along well.
cons: Very limited upward mobility because departments are very small. Moving up probably means moving outside of the institution. Additionally, the salaries are super low. I have a PhD and have been working there 7 years receiving EXCELLENT performance evaluations and I have yet to make $40k but the management has no problem asking you to serve on numerous advisory boards and volunteer for campus-wide events held after 5pm and on weekends.

pros: Mercer has plenty of money and is growing (and building) fast. I'm told they treat full-time employees quite well.
cons: My once-a-semester paycheck took weeks after semester's end to arrive. Also, university paperwork can be Kafkaesque because Mercer does not recognize its own official IDs as sufficient identification.

pros: Great school. Great professors. Great learning experience. Love the culture.
cons: Did not receive a job upon graduation. Difficult to begin career. Curriculum was broad rather than selecting a concentration, which puts a limit on specific skills and abilities (i.e. epidemiology).

review_title: I was a student employee in the University Center
pros: A great way to earn a little bit of cash to (mostly) study. Flexible schedule. Good managers.
cons: You'll be making minimum wage, but you really aren't working hard and the management knows you'll study mostly. They're happy as long as you get the 2-3 things done you really need to per shift.

review_title: One of the most underrated Universities in the country to teach at.
pros: Strong commitment to community, service-learning, with fellow academics at the top of their fields in research.
cons: Technologically, VERY behind. Legacy systems. Site and LMS that won't display on mobile devices.

pros: family like environment and really nice faculty and staff who cares about you .. ... .. .. .. .. .. .. .. .. .. .. .. ..
cons: small network and weak career services. nontraditional campus, very old facilities that needs to be updated,   .. .. ... .. .. .. ... ... .. ..

pros: Great community and it’s easy to believe that you are doing good work that helps others. Also, opportunities for travel.
cons: Travel can be very taxing and exhausting. You have to be prepared to give up some weekends and to work late often during peak times throughout the year.

pros: Not many honestly. There needs to be serious changes in the way management is handled.
cons: Not much room to advance unless you are already in a management position. Also, there are certain "rules" in place that don't allow you to get a pay raise.  Nothing to really offer you being a long-term employee.

pros: Working in the ticket sales department is great! Small, easy-going staff. Great job for students and is run by a great manager.
cons: Some departments are hard to work with when dealing with ticketing. Customers who get upset come with the territory so have a tough skin.

pros: Excellent educational opportunities, gracious and skilled faculty.  Located in a smaller Southern town, it is a solid experience.  The Medical School, Engineering School and Law School are the star departments.
cons: small town, lack of diversity

review_title: Mercer University has heart. It’s a great place to be a part of.
